III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry.
Description (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff at the facility have been stealing from children and instigating
unnecessary conflict.
Investigation On 9/2/25 Complainant submitted a letter to DCWL indicating
staff at the facility had been stealing from children and instigating
unnecessary conflict. As Complainant did not specify which
Independent Living (IL) house this was regarding, or which staff or
youth were involved, attempts were made to contact Complainant
on 9/4/25, 9/12/25, 9/16/25. However, no response was received.
Interviews:
Supervisor was contacted via email on 9/4/25, 9/11/25, and
9/17/25 to coordinate interviews. Supervisor indicated the program
had three Independent Living homes with twenty-five youth. As
Complainant did not specify which house the concern was about,
or which youth and staff were involved, it was determine all three
houses would be visited and a random sample would be
interviewed.
Interviews were completed with Staff 1 and Staff 2 at Washington
House on 9/23/25. Both staff reported they had not observed and
had not heard reports of any staff stealing from youth or instigating
conflict. Staff 1 reported that due to the nature of the allegations,
they believed the information was coming from Youth E, or their
family. Staff 1 reported Youth E was upset that staff would not
allow his boyfriend, that he recently met online, to live in the
house. Staff 1 explained to Youth E that it was against the rules
and not safe for other household members. Youth E left the
house, then returned with the family member to move their
belongings out of the home. Youth E’s family member provided an
alias to Staff 1. The alias was connected to Complainant.
Therefore, it was determined visits to the other two IL homes
would not be required as the complaints were regarding
Washington House.
2

Interviews were completed with Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and
Youth D at Washington House on 9/23/25. All four youth reported
they were not aware of any staff stealing from youth. All four youth
stated they had never observed staff to instigate conflict with
anyone. Youth C and Youth D indicated they were aware of a
situation in which Youth E had conflict with staff, as Youth E
wanted to have their boyfriend live in the home with them and staff
would not allow it. Youth E then left the home and did not return.
An interview was not completed with Youth E as they were AWOL
and a cell phone number was not listed.
Analysis No violation was found. Based on interviews with youth and staff,
there was no indication staff had stolen from youth or instigated
conflict.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement.
Section (1) An agency shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement that includes all the following information:
(c) Services provided.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation LGBTQ children are subjected to bias and discrimination by staff.
Investigation On 9/2/25 Complainant submitted a letter to DCWL indicating
LGBTQ youth are subjected to bias and discrimination by staff.
Attempts were made to contact Complainant on 9/4/25, 9/12/25,
9/16/25. However, no response was received.
Interviews:
Interviews were completed with Staff 1 and Staff 2 at Washington
House on 9/23/25. Both staff reported they had never been
witness to, or had youth report, any discriminatory behavior
toward LGBTQ youth. Both staff were aware of the anti-
discrimination policy at the agency and indicated they were
respectful to all youth.
Interviews were completed with Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and
Youth D at Washington House on 9/23/25. All four youth reported
they had never witnessed any discriminatory behavior toward
youth, specifically LGBTQ youth. Two youth identified as being
part of the LGBTQ community and stated they did not feel there
was any bias from staff.
3

An interview was not completed with Youth E as they were AWOL
and a cell phone number was not listed.
Documents reviewed:
Agency Policy ILP Program-Expression of Inherent Dignity:
Every youth is treated with respect and care, regardless of
background, expression, or personal journey. We prioritize
listening, empathy, and trust-building in all interactions.
• Staff will treat all youth with kindness and respect,
regardless of how they express or identify themselves.
• Names and pronouns will be used in a manner that reflects
sensitivity, balancing individual dignity with organizational
values. No youth will be subjected to ridicule, exclusion, or
coercion regarding their identity.
• Staff will not discriminate based upon a youth’s religion,
gender, race or sexual orientation.
Analysis No violation was found. Based on interviews with youth and staff,
there was no indication of discrimination or bias against youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
Section (3) An independent living home, staffed and operated by the child
Description placing agency, must be clean, safe, and appropriate to the needs
of the youth it serves.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth's basic needs are not being met, including inadequate food
and water, and substandard beds.
Investigation On 9/2/25 Complainant submitted a letter to DCWL indicating
youth’s basic needs are not being met, including adequate food,
water and substandard beds. Attempts were made to contact
Complainant on 9/4/25, 9/12/25, 9/16/25. However, no response
was received.
Interviews:
Interviews were completed with Staff 1 and Staff 2 at Washington
House on 9/23/25. Both staff reported all youth had sufficient
beds. Both staff stated that youth were responsible for their own
food and purchased food with their EBT card or money from their
IL stipend. Staff reported that some emergency food supplies
were kept on site and staff assisted youth with obtaining items
4

from the local food pantry if needed. Both staff noted that they
work with youth on weekly budgets to help them spend their
money wisely and not run out of food. Both staff also noted that
they moved to this house in August 2025. Prior to that, the youth
were in a house in Flint, MI and had well water, which the youth
did not like. The house in Flint had a water softener and water
filter. Staff also purchased bottled water to keep on hand for
youth. There were no reported water issues with the house they
currently occupy.
Interviews were completed with Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and
Youth D at Washington House on 9/23/25. All four youth reported
their beds were in good condition. All four youth reported they did
not have any problems with the water at the house. Youth C and
Youth D acknowledged the water at the previous house was not
good, but a filter was installed to improve the water and bottled
water was available. All four youth stated they were responsible
for purchasing their food. None of the youth reported ever running
out of food. Three of the four youth were aware of emergency food
assistance in the area and indicated staff would assist with
obtaining food if needed. The fourth youth was new to the
program and unaware of food resources but stated she would
speak with Staff 1 to obtain information.
Tour Observation:
On 9/23/25 an on-site inspection was completed. The facility was
found to be clean and organized. Three youth bedrooms were
viewed and found to have clean mattresses and bedding. Food
storage for youth was also observed and found to be sufficient.
The house had running water with no observable concerns.
Analysis No violation was found. Based on observation of the IL home and
interviews with youth and staff, there was no indication basic
needs of youth have not been met.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
